awd_titl_txt: "Collaborative Research: Digitization TCN: Developing a Centralized Digital Archive of Vouchered Animal Communication Signals"
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to establish a thematic collection network that will digitize and make accessible media recordings associated with physical voucher specimens, broadly organized around the research theme of understanding the evolution and ecology of communication signals. Research on these questions has been challenged by the relative inaccessibility of the signal recordings and their associated physical specimens. This project will meet this challenge by partnering together multiple biological research collections and the Macaulay Library of Natural Sounds, the world's largest scientific archive of animal signal recordings. Collectively, these institutions will co-curate and make accessible digitized and vouchered recordings of the communication signals of birds, frogs, fish and insects, and will establish direct and transparent links across collections between physical voucher specimens and their digitized recordings. This project will make accessible digital audio recordings of animal signals that can be used to address a host of scientific questions, including the responses of animals to anthropogenic noise and other human activities. By providing a useful co-curation system and encouraging collection of recordings along with physical specimens, this project will have a transformative influence on the way that researchers collect and use biological specimens in the future, and will serve as a useful model for collections facing similar co-curation challenges. 

This project will also provide materials for extensive educational outreach at all age levels, and will have significant conservation impacts because the digitized material will contribute directly to our ability to assess and monitor biodiversity. Finally, this project will expand biological collection methods and help train the "next generation" of museum curators, collectors, and researchers. This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource (iDigBio.org).

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this subaward to the California Academy of Sciences were two-fold. The first was to properly label, provide unique identification numbers, and suitably house for permanent storage specimens of (a) tree crickets of the genus Oecanthus from the Laurel Symes collection and (b) field crickets of the genus Gryllus from the David Weissman collection. The second was to create, populate and make publicly accessible a database with information about each specimen, including where, when, and by whom it was collected and its Macaulay Library sound recoding number. These data are now available for more than 5,200 cricket specimens online at :

https://monarch.calacademy.or/collections/listtabledisplay.phy?taxa=Gryllidae&thes=1&type=1&db=3;Goccindex=1&sortfield1=Catalog%20Number&sortfield2=&sortoder=asc

This effort now permits anyone to associate sound recordings included in the Macaulay Library of natural sounds at Cornell University in New York with individual cricket specimens preserved and housed in the Entomology Collection at the California Academy of Sciences in San Francisco. The scientific value and general usefulness of both the preserved cricket specimens and the recordings of the sound communications they generated while alive is greatly enhanced by bringing these traditionally separate elements together in a single database. Many cricket species are very difficult to tell apart by simply comparing their anatomic features; but the sounds they make to communicate with other members of their own species may be very different from the sounds made by members of other species and so the recordings can aid with identification. Conversely, the physical specimens serve as vouchers for the sound recordings and thereby help to validate the identity of the recordings themselves.

This project was a first attempt to integrate these different types of information and provide a single access point through which to explore the available information about these crickets and their communications. Hopefully, this project will serve as a model for similar efforts with other groups of animals and their communications in the future. We anticipate that information made available through this project and any similar projects to follow will have significant conservation impacts because verifiably identified sound recordings can contribute directly to our ability to assess and monitor biodiversity with minimal impact on that biodiversity and the environment.


Last Modified: 04/05/2018
Modified by: David H Kavanaugh
